results.title: Directions
results.creator_credit: Brian Adams and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Landscape with figures: the art of Australia”.
One of a series in which Robert Hughes surveys Australia’s art from the time of the first fleet to the present day. This episode focuses on Twentieth Century landscape imagery, the leaders of this style were Olsen, Rose and Smith. Other artists whose work is discussed include Godfrey Miller, Ian Fairweather, Fred Williams and Brett Whitely. Written and narrated by Robert Hughes.

results.title: Chains of arcady
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Landscape with figures: the art of Australia”.
One of a series in which Robert Hughes surveys Australia’s art from the time of the first fleet to the present day. Covers mainly the convict artists of Australia’s early days. Discusses the works of Thomas Watling, Joseph Lycett, Conrad Martens, John Glover, William Gould, Augustus Earle and Thomas Boch. Commentary by Robert Hughes. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Wood ducks and tyre-kickers
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Landscape with figures: the art of Australia”.
One of a series in which Robert Hughes surveys Australia’s art from the time of the first fleet to the present day. In this final program, Hughes assesses the commercial and social backgrounds against which Australian art operates and looks at a government sponsored exhibition of 10 artists in Paris in 1974.

results.title: Iraq: cradle of civilisation
results.creator_credit: Peter Spry-Leverton, Central Productions, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, Maryland Public Television and ITV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Legacy”.
Filmed just before and just after the Gulf War, the first program in this series looks at the effects of “civilisation” on the landscape, and the rise and fall of civilisations, particularly in relation to Iraq where civilisation began. The first cities were built 5000 years ago on the banks of the Euphrates in Southern Iraq, and city life soon transformed the human race with the glorious cultures of Mesopotamia such as Ur, Nineveh and Babylon. Michael Woods explores these ancient cultures and the legacy they gave to the history of Iraq right up to the Gulf War. The program is presented in two parts.

results.title: The Antipodeans (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Landscape with figures: the art of Australia”.
One of a series in which Robert Hughes surveys Australia’s art from the time of the first fleet to the present day. Arthur Boyd and John Perceval had progressed through the ‘angry decade’ and younger painters joined them: Robert Dickerson, Charles Blackman, John Brack, Clifton Pugh and David Boyd, and two greats who were to influence the future, Sidney Nolan and Leonard French.
results.description:

results.title: China: the mandate of heaven
results.creator_credit: Peter Spry-Leverton, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, Maryland Public Television and ITV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Legacy”.
China was the last of the great civilisations to develop independently, but it developed a vision of life unique to itself, centred on two quite separate philosophies - moral order, sustained by ritual, as taught by Confucius and the mysticism of Taoism, or the search for the”right way”. Chinese history is permeated by the search for harmony, and a belief in the self-sufficiency and order of Chinese culture, so that outside contact has been viewed as unnecessary and mostly discouraged - even to the present day.

results.title: The Angry decade (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Brian Adams and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Landscape with figures: the art of Australia”.
One of a series in which Robert Hughes surveys Australia’s art from the time of the first fleet to the present day. A look at Australia’s ‘angry young men’ - painters of the Depression Era: Danila Vassilieff, Sidney Nolan, Albert Tucker, John Perceval and Arthur Boyd. Narrated by Robert Hughes.
